segments.text: Every week I spend hours tracking what's
actually happening in AI. Not the
headlines, but the shifts underneath.
There were over 200 stories I kept an
eye on over the last week or so. And I
think five of them really matter. I'm
going to get to those five right away.
Starting with the healthc care race. So
let me start with what Open AI and
Anthropic actually did because the press
coverage missed the point entirely. So
OpenAI launched two products. They
launched Chad GPC health for consumers
which was very widely covered where you
can sync your health data. can ask
questions about your body. And they also
launched OpenAI for health care for
enterprises, which is a HIPPA compliant
API. It has hospital system
integrations. It's designed to work at
scale. Enthropic followed up 5 days
later with claude for healthcare, which
features connectors to CMS databases and
insurance claim systems. Obviously, the
larger surface story is AI comes to
medicine. Certainly part of the consumer
story is that we can see from chat
volume that consumers talk about health
matters with LLMs regularly. And so to
some extent the easiest read of this is
that this is a defensive play by both
chat GPT and Claude because if you are
talking with consumers about personal
health matters you have a higher
standard of care you have to exercise
and it probably justifies the product
investment on that basis alone. But I
think there's another story here. The
graveyard of healthcare AI is vast and
well populated and it is tempting to see
these skeptically as a result. I'm going
to give you an example. IBM Watson did
an oncology product a few years ago. It
was supposed to revolutionize cancer
care. It had some great initial results.
It got sold for parts in 2022. Google's
deep mind has done a great job with
protein folding and we have various
drugs inspired by AI in the drug
pipeline but to be honest none has yet
hit the market and become a hit has none
has yet reached millions of people so
the natural question to ask when AI
launches a healthcare product is what's
different now here's the story I think
nobody is talking about both companies
are approaching the public markets and
they need a story that is a little bit
different from chatbot for consumers or
just chatbot for work. Healthcare
provides a really compelling IPO story.
And you might think this is really
early. Neither company has announced an
IPO date. Why would we care about IPO at
this point? I would argue back if you
want a thriving healthc care story that
can be part of your public company
narrative, you got to start early. You
got to start early. So you have existing
partnerships with hospitals. You have
health care data that's working. You
could talk about millions of consumers
benefiting from using your product for
health care. That narrative takes time
to develop. It is time to start now. And
think about how much power that
narrative has. Right? You're in a
regulated industry which suggests the
seriousness of the business. You have
HIPPA compliance versus technical
sophistication. You have hospital
partnerships which suggest enterprise
credibility. It's a good story for
investors. And not to mention in the US
you have the rising spend on health care
which investors read as rising revenue
if you're in that space for better or
worse. Right now I want to be careful
here. I'm not saying that the health
care products that Anthropic and OpenAI
launched are just vaporware. I'm
actually saying the opposite. So for
example the prior authorization use case
Anthropic called out when they launched
where a doctor submits paperwork to an
insurance company for treatment
approval. That's a $30 billion annual
administrative burden. That is a real
business. So I think many things can be
true at once. The healthc care story can
be both a story about these major model
makers responding to real consumer
existing demand for healthcare advice
from AI and also a story about
positioning themselves into a growing
spend category in the economy that they
can play on as they start to court
public investors. eventually maybe late
26 maybe late 27 we don't have an idea
yet when those IPO dates will be the
larger question if we're thinking
strategically is what happens to the
healthcare AI market structure if both
major foundation model companies are
competing directly and this is worth
thinking about regardless of healthcare
because I think we'll see this in other
places as well because every healthcare
AI startup just had their build versus
buy calculation rewritten why would a
hospital system partner with a
healthcare AI startup when they can get
HIPPA compliant claude or chat GPT
directly from source. One of the things
that we're learning is that because AI
makes it easy to write code, AI makes it
easy to build out new features on an
existing platform if you have
distribution as both Anthropic and Chat
GPT do to differing degrees. And that
means that when they see a successful
pattern, when they see something they
want to build into, they're able to
build into that space very quickly and
efficiently. and they then pose a very
tricky set of problems to smaller
startups in that space. This is less a
big company problem and more a startup
question. Foundation model companies are
moving down the stack into vertical
applications. They're not content just
to be the API that startups build on.
They want to get application revenue
where they see interesting use cases. So
if you're building an AI startup in any
vertical, what you should be asking
yourself is if OpenAI launches a product
with the same underlying model and their
distribution, what happens to us? What's
our differentiator at that point? So the
healthcare announcements are partly
about healthcare, but they're also about
vertical integration and I think they're
about starting to tell stories that will
be appealing in the public markets and I
think that's getting overlooked. Second
big story, what Yan Lun's departure
actually means. So Yan Lun left Meta
after more than a decade and he said a
lot on the way out. So to give you some
context, Lacun is one of three people
credited with the deep learning
revolution alongside Jeffrey Hinton and
Yoshua Beno. He's not he's not a middle
manager. He's one of the founders of the
field and he let loose in a Financial
Times interview. First, he confirmed
that Meta fudged their llama for
benchmarks using different model
variants for different tests to inflate
scores, which I don't know, whatever he
signed, he decided he didn't care.
Second, he said Mark Zuckerberg
basically lost confidence in everyone
who was involved in the Llama for
release after discovering that the
benchmarks were fudged and quote
sideline the entire GEI organization,
which makes sense looking in from the
outside. And that is why he brought in
new leadership. That is why he went on
that spending spree to bring in new
people. Most importantly though, Lun
continued to say that LLMs are a dead
end that don't lead to super
intelligence. He has been saying that
for a while and it is one of the most
fundamental differences in Silicon
Valley and every now and then it's worth
revisiting so we stay current because
someone has to be very wrong. Either Lun
is out of touch and LLMs have no scaling
wall and will keep going toward AGI or
he's right and a lot of the folks who
are pouring lots of money into AI and
scaling are going to find out that
they're overshooting and other founders
Dario Amade comes to mind will be very
honest about the fact that they have not
seen the top of the scaling wall but by
definition you can't see it till it
appears and so this is an example of a
lot of very smart people certainly much
smarter than me or you arguing over
something that nobody can prove until
they run into it. And so essentially Lun
is saying fundamentally LLMs cannot
build world models. They don't possess
the attributes needed for intelligence.
I'm going to found my own startup and he
is that is going to work on a different
path to intelligence. If this reminds
you of Ilia Sutsgiver, it should. But
while he goes that way, we continue to
see gains in agents doing longer and
longer and longer tasks. all report on a
new record just later in this video. And
we don't see an end to scaling with
LLMs. We don't see gaps in
generalization pace of gains. And I want
to be precise about that because LLMs as
a whole still have some fragile
generalization abilities. They still
don't generalize as well as humans do,
but they are getting better and better
and better and better and they are
closing gaps. So, I don't know who's
right. I'm letting you know that there
is a big fight between some of the
smartest people in the world and we're
all going to get to sit on the sidelines
and figure out who's right over the next
couple of years because it will take
just one or two more years to see who is
correct about reaching AGI and that's
one of the exciting things about being
alive right now. The next story is about
physical AI. So obviously Nvidia
launched the Reuben platform at CES. We
talked about that last week. In the same
week, Google DeepMind and Boston Dynamic
announced a partnership to put Gemini
Foundation model into Atlas robots with
initial deployment in highendai
factories. And Nvidia also at the same
time unveiled its Alpa NIO family of
open AI models. Open AAI not meaning the
company meaning literally open models
for autonomous vehicles. And Jensen, who
loves to find a good line and he's so
good at it, said the Chad GPT moment for
robotics is here. which I think is a
great summary. So, let me dive in a
little bit to what's being built on the
robotics side because it's not entirely
clear from the wealth of announcements
that appeared. So, for the past couple
of years, the AI story has been about
language models, chat bots, coding
assistance, text generation, you you get
the idea. What has changed, what has
turned robots from coming soon into here
now is a convergence of three
technologies that had not previously
worked together. First, foundation
models can now do genuine multimodal
reasoning. So, if you get Claude, if you
get Gemini, if you get Chat GPT, they
can look at an image and understand
what's in it and reason about spatial
relationships and generate plans. This
is the perception and reasoning layer
that a lot of robots have had trouble
with in the past. Second, simulation
environments are now quite good.
Nvidia's Omniverse and similar platforms
can create synthetic scenarios that
transfer to real world performance. Now,
Omniverse was not a great hit when it
came out last year, but I think
directionally it shows where you can go
to solve the data problem because we've
seen very successful data problem
solutions in a similar private company
environment, not in Nvidia, but at
Tesla, where Tesla used lots and lots
and lots and lots of training data to
solve autonomous driving. Third, edge
inference chips are here and they have
become powerful enough to run real
models on the robot rather than from the
server. And that is a big technical
breakthrough. So Nvidia's Jetson T4000,
which was announced at CES this year, it
delivers four times the AI compute of
previous generations inside the same
power envelope. And so the robot does
not need to phone home as much to make a
decision. Now, Nvidia's at the heart of
all of this, as you would expect. And
here's their strategic play. They're
building the full stack for physical AI
from data center training
infrastructure, think Ruben, to edge
inference, think Jetson, to simulation,
to open models like Alpaio. They want to
be the platform that all of us are
building robots on, regardless of
whether those robots come from Boston
Dynamics or a Chinese manufacturer or
Tesla. The Boston Dynamics partnership
is particularly interesting because it's
explicitly described as a data
collection exercise. So, Gemini powered
Atlas robots will work in high-end
factories and the data from those
deployments will train the next
generation of models. And this is the
beginning of an interesting
manufacturing flywheel for robotics
because you're going to be able to
deploy robots. You're going to be able
to collect data to train better models
to deploy better and faster robots that
speeds up fast. The strategic question
is whether physical AI follows the same
scaling dynamics as language models
because if it does, the first movers who
accumulate embodied data are going to
have compounding advantages. And of
course, Nvidia by positioning itself as
the infrastructure layer is going to win
regardless of which robot company
succeeds. Now, there's always the harder
question. Is physical AI actually closer
now or is this just another false dawn?
I've been watching the space for a while
and this is what makes me a little bit
more optimistic this time. It's the
foundational model piece. Previous
generation of robots were just brittle
because they were too hardcoded on
perception systems. We now have much
more flexible perception systems. We
have early indications in December of
2025 and January of 2026 that models are
starting to be able to generalize from
video and learn on their own how to take
actions. I think we are at a point where
we are starting to see the first
indicators of a flywheel forming around
robotics. And I think a lot of the story
of 2026 is going to be about the
companies that figure out how to take
the first turn or two at that flywheel
so that they can begin to accumulate
knowledge and make better robotic
systems heading into 2027 2028. So the
practical implication is that if you're
in an industry that involves physical
operations, you need to change your
narrative from the robots are coming to
the robots are around and we need to
figure out when to get a robot into
place and start to learn and get that
flywheel turning. Next story, the
training data is exhausted. This is
buried, right? It was very hard to find
this, but I think it's super
significant. It was in a wired report
that OpenAI and a company called
Handshake AI are asking contractors to
upload real on the job work from past
employers. The examples requested
include Word docs, PDFs, PowerPoints,
Excel files, images, and code repos. By
the way, if you're worried about AI
leaking to AI, maybe you should worry
more about former employees leaking doc.
Contractors are told to delete
proprietary and personal identifiable
information. Sure, I don't know that it
always happens. Now the story got almost
no attention but it is strategically
significant because it suggests that the
easy training data is exhausted. The
public internet is no longer useful. It
has been scraped. Books have been
scraped. The next frontier of capability
improvement requires data that isn't
currently existing in any accessible
form. The actual work products that
people create in their jobs. Think about
what that means. Large language models
are trained on text that was written to
be read. But most of the valuable work
in the economy isn't written to be
widely read. It's in internal documents,
in project files, in analysis
spreadsheets. That's the data that would
let AI do the knowledge work, not just
discuss it. And OpenAI is trying to
acquire that data by essentially paying
contractors to upload previous work. And
that's a brute force approach. It raises
pretty obvious legal and ethical
questions, but it reveals the strategic
priority. Whoever assembles the best
corpus of how people actually do work
will have a significant advantage in
building AI that can do the work. And
this connects into that larger physical
AI story, doesn't it? The reason robot
training has been hard is the same
reason knowledge work has been hard.
Relevant data is hard to get in
accessible form. And that is why this
partnership with Highendai is really
significant. The implication for
companies is that your internal data is
about to become strategically valuable
in a way it never was. The work products
that your teams create, the processes
they follow, that's training data that
somebody is going to want to improve AI
systems. And the question is how you
either capture that value yourself or
how you protect it so it doesn't leak
out to foundation model companies. I
also think the Claude code story
deserves more attention. Claude Code
blew up on X over December and into
January as an emergent phenomenon where
people were talking about running their
Claude code to do all sorts of things
from growing tomatoes to wiring up their
homes. Boris Churnney, the creator of
Claude Code, shared his own workflow
just this past week. He runs five to 10
Claude instances at the same time. Uses
Opus 4.5 exclusively and maintains a
file with claude.mmarkdown where every
mistake Claude makes is converted into a
permanent rule. So his claws get better
over time. By maintaining a single
markdown file with a lot of rules for
Claude to review before submitting work,
Boris can supervise Claude much more
lightly. Now he's a coder. He's an
engineer. So a lot of what Claude is
doing for him is coding tasks. And so a
lot of his rules are effectively rules
that Claude's PRs or engineering code
submissions have to pass in order to be
successful. Most of those individual
attempts may fail, but because Boris has
rigged up five or 10 parallel cloud
instances to constantly check against a
regularly updated rule set, he can just
kind of sit back a little bit, focus on
what he wants to build, and let Claude
iterate until it gets it right. That's
an example of how fast the frontier is
moving. And I found another example from
chat GPT that's even more eyeopening. So
this past week, Michael Tru, who is a
co-founder at Cursor, shared that they
built a browser, an internet browser
from scratch, from nothing, using chat
GPT 5.2. It ran uninterrupted for, wait
for it, an entire week, and it produced
3 million lines of code. It produced a
rendering engine in Rust with HTML
parsing, a CSS cascade, layout, text
shaping, the ability to paint pixels,
and a custom JavaScript VM. Now, Michael
was honest. He said it kind of works.
Simple websites render quickly and
largely correctly. It's not yet close to
Chromium parody. Chromium famously is
the browser engine that powers Chrome
and many other browsers. But let the
core concept sink in here. Building a
browser engine is one of the hardest
tasks in software engineering. There are
only three rendering engines in the
world. Chromium for Chrome, Gecko for
Firefox, and WebKit for Safari. Each
represents thousands of engineer years
of work. Now, there's a fourth written
by a single agent running for a week.
Now, true is clear. There's some issues.
It's not yet matching real browsers, but
that's precisely what makes this
credible. We're not trying to cherrypick
an example here. We're talking about an
agent that produced a functional version
of an extremely complicated system in a
time frame that would have been
unthinkable 3 months ago. And this is
the larger story behind the clawed code
explosion. I think people think about it
as is it cla
I'm stepping back and what I'm realizing
is the capabilities that we see in Opus
4.5 and chat GPT 5.2 have crossed a
tipping point for builders. The
excitement we see is not tool driven. It
is around the capabilities that these
tools are enabling all of us to unlock
together. And that's why I deliberately
highlighted stories from both chat GPT
and Claude because I think the larger
story around the Claude code enthusiasm
is that it's not Claude codec coded, pun
intended. It is actually about the
ability to build things and how quickly
that's tipped over. Now again, the
browser doesn't compete with Chrome.
Don't look for it to compete with
Chrome, but get a sense of where the
capability curve is at. Coding is
progressing extremely quickly because
it's very easy to retry. It's very easy
to see success criteria and it's very
easy to run a feedback loop. One of the
big challenges of 2026 is how AI agents
will progress very quickly in a domain
where the feedback loop is not as
consistent and the success criteria is
more ambiguous like the rest of
knowledge work. Help me with my email.
analyze this situation. Those are more
complicated than coding tasks for AI.
This week, Anthropic released Claude
co-work and is positioned as Claude code
for the rest of your work and it's laser
focused on that second challenge. It's a
sandboxed environment where Claude can
access files and execute actions and
complete multi-step tasks. I did a whole
video on it. Whether it works depends on
whether users can define success
criteria for non-coding tasks. That is
hard because users are often not able to
articulate themselves that clearly. Now
to Claude's credit, when I have done
testing with Claude Co-work, what I have
found is that they have done some
training and iterating on that model so
that if you have common work tasks, you
can use generally correct English
commands that are not very long to
invoke a very useful piece of work. And
so what I mean by that if you is if you
say something like please make me a nice
presentation using this data they have
done enough training on claude that it
can get to a presentation that's pretty
good even if it feels sort of in the
typical claude aesthetic style. So I
think the encouraging thing is just as
we saw earlier in this video, AI
companies are using work product, real
work product from real companies to
train these models so that we can use
somewhat vague English in order to get
decent work product back. that still
leaves room for people who want to do
excellent work to get better at
prompting to get better at defining
outputs and defining correctness in
knowledge work and to get extraordinary
results from new tools like claude
co-work and so I think the larger story
of the whole cloud code moment is that
these models have tipped over into new
capability layer people are very excited
and we are going to try the next big
challenge which cla coowork is the first
sign of and that is getting AI to start
to really dig into knowledge work So
where does this leave us overall? The AI
industry spent the last 3 years building
capability sets, right? Models kept
getting bigger, benchmarks kept
improving, demos got more and more
impressive. The assumption was that that
capability would translate into value.
That better models would mean more
products and revenue. That assumption is
being tested this year. We are finding
out this year whether getting into
health care matters, whether getting
into clawed co-work is going to work,
whether getting into physical AI will
scale. And so the AI industry as a whole
is discovering what is compounding and
valuable out of all of the
experimentation that we've done in the
past couple of years. And we as the
users, as the builders are going to be a
part of figuring out what truly has
value here. So if I leave you with one
thing, if you're in physical work at
all, robotics needs to be on your mind.
And if you're in software at all, you
got to play with claude co-work. Both of
those are big stories that have to do
with that compounding piece that we all
get to be a part of. All right, have
fun. Get building. That's the news for
the

fullText: Every week I spend hours tracking what's actually happening in AI. Not the headlines, but the shifts underneath. There were over 200 stories I kept an eye on over the last week or so. And I think five of them really matter. I'm going to get to those five right away. Starting with the healthc care race. So let me start with what Open AI and Anthropic actually did because the press coverage missed the point entirely. So OpenAI launched two products. They launched Chad GPC health for consumers which was very widely covered where you can sync your health data. can ask questions about your body. And they also launched OpenAI for health care for enterprises, which is a HIPPA compliant API. It has hospital system integrations. It's designed to work at scale. Enthropic followed up 5 days later with claude for healthcare, which features connectors to CMS databases and insurance claim systems. Obviously, the larger surface story is AI comes to medicine. Certainly part of the consumer story is that we can see from chat volume that consumers talk about health matters with LLMs regularly. And so to some extent the easiest read of this is that this is a defensive play by both chat GPT and Claude because if you are talking with consumers about personal health matters you have a higher standard of care you have to exercise and it probably justifies the product investment on that basis alone. But I think there's another story here. The graveyard of healthcare AI is vast and well populated and it is tempting to see these skeptically as a result. I'm going to give you an example. IBM Watson did an oncology product a few years ago. It was supposed to revolutionize cancer care. It had some great initial results. It got sold for parts in 2022. Google's deep mind has done a great job with protein folding and we have various drugs inspired by AI in the drug pipeline but to be honest none has yet hit the market and become a hit has none has yet reached millions of people so the natural question to ask when AI launches a healthcare product is what's different now here's the story I think nobody is talking about both companies are approaching the public markets and they need a story that is a little bit different from chatbot for consumers or just chatbot for work. Healthcare provides a really compelling IPO story. And you might think this is really early. Neither company has announced an IPO date. Why would we care about IPO at this point? I would argue back if you want a thriving healthc care story that can be part of your public company narrative, you got to start early. You got to start early. So you have existing partnerships with hospitals. You have health care data that's working. You could talk about millions of consumers benefiting from using your product for health care. That narrative takes time to develop. It is time to start now. And think about how much power that narrative has. Right? You're in a regulated industry which suggests the seriousness of the business. You have HIPPA compliance versus technical sophistication. You have hospital partnerships which suggest enterprise credibility. It's a good story for investors. And not to mention in the US you have the rising spend on health care which investors read as rising revenue if you're in that space for better or worse. Right now I want to be careful here. I'm not saying that the health care products that Anthropic and OpenAI launched are just vaporware. I'm actually saying the opposite. So for example the prior authorization use case Anthropic called out when they launched where a doctor submits paperwork to an insurance company for treatment approval. That's a $30 billion annual administrative burden. That is a real business. So I think many things can be true at once. The healthc care story can be both a story about these major model makers responding to real consumer existing demand for healthcare advice from AI and also a story about positioning themselves into a growing spend category in the economy that they can play on as they start to court public investors. eventually maybe late 26 maybe late 27 we don't have an idea yet when those IPO dates will be the larger question if we're thinking strategically is what happens to the healthcare AI market structure if both major foundation model companies are competing directly and this is worth thinking about regardless of healthcare because I think we'll see this in other places as well because every healthcare AI startup just had their build versus buy calculation rewritten why would a hospital system partner with a healthcare AI startup when they can get HIPPA compliant claude or chat GPT directly from source. One of the things that we're learning is that because AI makes it easy to write code, AI makes it easy to build out new features on an existing platform if you have distribution as both Anthropic and Chat GPT do to differing degrees. And that means that when they see a successful pattern, when they see something they want to build into, they're able to build into that space very quickly and efficiently. and they then pose a very tricky set of problems to smaller startups in that space. This is less a big company problem and more a startup question. Foundation model companies are moving down the stack into vertical applications. They're not content just to be the API that startups build on. They want to get application revenue where they see interesting use cases. So if you're building an AI startup in any vertical, what you should be asking yourself is if OpenAI launches a product with the same underlying model and their distribution, what happens to us? What's our differentiator at that point? So the healthcare announcements are partly about healthcare, but they're also about vertical integration and I think they're about starting to tell stories that will be appealing in the public markets and I think that's getting overlooked. Second big story, what Yan Lun's departure actually means. So Yan Lun left Meta after more than a decade and he said a lot on the way out. So to give you some context, Lacun is one of three people credited with the deep learning revolution alongside Jeffrey Hinton and Yoshua Beno. He's not he's not a middle manager. He's one of the founders of the field and he let loose in a Financial Times interview. First, he confirmed that Meta fudged their llama for benchmarks using different model variants for different tests to inflate scores, which I don't know, whatever he signed, he decided he didn't care. Second, he said Mark Zuckerberg basically lost confidence in everyone who was involved in the Llama for release after discovering that the benchmarks were fudged and quote sideline the entire GEI organization, which makes sense looking in from the outside. And that is why he brought in new leadership. That is why he went on that spending spree to bring in new people. Most importantly though, Lun continued to say that LLMs are a dead end that don't lead to super intelligence. He has been saying that for a while and it is one of the most fundamental differences in Silicon Valley and every now and then it's worth revisiting so we stay current because someone has to be very wrong. Either Lun is out of touch and LLMs have no scaling wall and will keep going toward AGI or he's right and a lot of the folks who are pouring lots of money into AI and scaling are going to find out that they're overshooting and other founders Dario Amade comes to mind will be very honest about the fact that they have not seen the top of the scaling wall but by definition you can't see it till it appears and so this is an example of a lot of very smart people certainly much smarter than me or you arguing over something that nobody can prove until they run into it. And so essentially Lun is saying fundamentally LLMs cannot build world models. They don't possess the attributes needed for intelligence. I'm going to found my own startup and he is that is going to work on a different path to intelligence. If this reminds you of Ilia Sutsgiver, it should. But while he goes that way, we continue to see gains in agents doing longer and longer and longer tasks. all report on a new record just later in this video. And we don't see an end to scaling with LLMs. We don't see gaps in generalization pace of gains. And I want to be precise about that because LLMs as a whole still have some fragile generalization abilities. They still don't generalize as well as humans do, but they are getting better and better and better and better and they are closing gaps. So, I don't know who's right. I'm letting you know that there is a big fight between some of the smartest people in the world and we're all going to get to sit on the sidelines and figure out who's right over the next couple of years because it will take just one or two more years to see who is correct about reaching AGI and that's one of the exciting things about being alive right now.
